Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

I' :! Il ! || 1%! !l :!I :l ’



way at ramps onto Mulberry Street just west of Myrtle Avenue or onto
Eager Street between Cathedral Street and Charles Street. The north-
south streets from these ramps to the central business district are all
heavily congested.

The Harbor Route, on the other hand, passes close to the western
boundary of the central business district and then along its southern
boundary. Numerous ramps along this route would provide ready access
between the Harbor Route and the central business district at a number
of strategic points, notably close to the retail trade center, Charles Center,
the Civic Center, and the financial center.

Studies have shown that the bulk of central business district employ-
ment comes from the northeast, the north, and the northwest. The Har-
bor Route expressway system would provide improved access from the
northeast, while the completion of the inner ring would allow traffic com-
ing in from the north or northwest to choose expressways running along
the east boundary of the central business district or the west. Either
choice would merge with an expressway along the south of the central
business district.

It might be said that completion of the inner ring as part of the
Northern Route system would follow the same line along the western
side of the central business district between Mulberry and Pratt Streets
as is proposed for the Harbor Route and thus would permit equally good
access, at least to the retail trade center. A question of timing is involved,
however. If the Northern Route is used for the East-West Expressway
the Mulberry-Pratt connection to complete the inner ring would not be
built until some time thereafter. If the Harbor Route is selected the
Mulberry-Pratt Street connection would be built at a much earlier date
as part of the East-West Expressway. At a rough guess, the tie-in between
the retail trade center and the expressway system would come at least

S0

10 years earlier with the Harbor Route than with the Northern Route.

Even if no question of timing were involved, the Harbor Route would
still provide better access to the retail trade center than would the com-
pletion of the inner ring under the Northern Route system. Access from
the east and west would be no different, but traffic coming from the north
on the Jones Falls Expressway could not, as design is now proceeding,
turn right on the Northern Route. Jones Falls Expressway traffic headed
for the retail trade center would be forced to do one of three things:

(a) Leave the Jones Falls Expressway at 29th Street and proceed by
surface streets to a tie-in with the Northern Route at Cathedral
Street. (Sheet 20.)

(b) Follow all the way round the inner ring in a clock-wise direction
to about Lexington Street west of the retail trade center. This
would allow the trip to be made all on expressways but would
add two to three miles to the trip.

(c) Leave the Jones Falls Expressway at some intermediate point
(such as Lexington Street near the City Hall) and cross the
central business district on surface streets.

It is obvious that even after the inner ring is completed access from

the north to the retail trade center would be poorer under the Northern
Route system than under the Harbor Route system.

Benefits to the City’s Economy

Any improvement which increases accessibility between the various
sections of a metropolitan area is of benefit to the economy of the area,
and in this general sense either the Northern Route or the Harbor Route
would be helpful. More specifically, however, it is possible to isolate
certain key aspects of Baltimore’s economy and to discover significant
differences between the impact on these aspects of the two routes.
